data.text: How to Keep Yourself and Your Clothes Clean when Wild Camping?

Those of you who wild camp, how to you keep yourself and your clothes clean? Easy if I could find streams of water, but not much that's accessible and clean enough here. I'm on a trip in Vosges, France where I'd wild camp every night if this and charging weren't an issue. I have a son28 dynamo hub, but I'm mostly off road on technical trails so don't go fast enough to charge.
I’m cycling through the Vosges now and where we are we’re not even filtering the water for drinking. We’re also using a solar charger and wild camping every night.
data.author: John McAndrew

data.text: Ortlieb bag as washing "machine" filled at cafés, restaurants, etc. It leaks when closed, that's normal.
data.author: Roland Okello

data.text: , I uses one of my drybags for this.
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: Wet wipes if you want to get clean and a campsite every 2 weeks or so to do washing in a shower easy.
data.author: Tim Swain

data.text: , the wet wipes works. So does a light flannel and a surprisingly small amount of water. BUt rather than only washing clothes every two weeks ( gee, carrying a lot of clothes? Or smelling rather strong?) my preference is to seize any opportunity to rinse out an item of clothing, preferably each evening - waiting for a long period doesn't work if it's raining by that time.)
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: Water (warm if you have the means) n tide pack in a dry bag. Shake alot. Shake More. Rinse w water a bunch and hang (incl bag inside out)
data.author: Tom Middaugh

data.text: , YES!! 😃
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: ??????? Wild camping doesn't mean I can't leave... I wild camp overnight and then I'm on the road again passing streams and towns and houses. When I'm riding, I'll rinse my clothes that need it and let them dry while I ride..... I've never visited a laundry while touring.
data.author: Samuel Lea

data.text: You should be able to charge from yourSON28 even at low speeds - if you have the right device to convert the ac current. I rode the Great Divide and Baja Divide on a fat bike in my late 50s, and was able to charge even as slow as I was. I was using a Sinewave to convert. Now I use a converter by klite - if you want to know more about that sort of stuff then Kerry at klite would help.
data.author: Peter Gordon

data.text: I also use the gear by klite. I wonder if there's something wrong with any of my gear? I have a nitecore power bank, and it has barely charged this trip. Compared to the last trip where I was on more compact gravel and going at higher speeds, then it would easily charge up throughout the day. Notably, I did have to replace my converter between trips (I lost the initial one).
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: Don’t know - maybe the power bank?? Wish I could help but that’s about the extent of my knowledge
data.author: Peter Gordon

data.text: OK, I'll test that out. It should charge fully in an hour or so if plugged into a wall socket, right? I think it took longer than that yesterday.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: Wild camping is great but you do need to have the knowledge and skills to do this with minimal impact on the environment. I would suggest that if you are washing clothes with detergent then it is good practice to take the water and the washing away from the stream.
data.author: Garry James

data.text: , that's not really a very helpful post for sharing knowledge; just condemning. I see nothing wrong in rinsing clothes in a stream (or oneself) - just don't add soap of any kind. Filling a bag with stream water ( a drybag for example) and taking it away from the stream to wash, also works well.
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: Sorry, it didn’t come out the way I meant it.
data.author: Garry James

data.text: , you're forgiven! 😛
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: Garry James you gave a suggestion..and it was fine. He basically just said the same thing..don't use soap in a stream.
data.author: Tim Trepanier

data.text: I have been known to warm a small pan of water on a stove for a strip wash. Can do most of the body with 500ml if you're careful. Might need a second one for hair depending how much of it you have!!
data.author: Hannah Milton

data.text: exactly!! 500ml of warm water & a microfibre cloth…..it is the cloth that gets the dirt off , rinse , squeeze out ,wipe-wipe. A second 500ml sometimes for a repeat head to ankle. Feet get done last
data.author: Philip Palmer

data.text: ooh, this is a great idea! Love it!
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: I also just saw the second half of your question - get yourself a fast charge wire and treat yourself to a meal in a friendly cafe along the route where you can ask nicely to plug in your device while you eat. Also make sure your bike lights are turned off in daytime to maximise dynamo usb charging.
data.author: Hannah Milton

data.text: What you wear also makes a difference the quick dry fabric made for camping is a great help. A rinse in any available water and then strap it on my rear rack. Dries in less than an hour.
data.author: Marshall Parsons

data.text: yeah, all my clothing is quick dry.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: We love our merino wool that never smells bad and drys quickly if washing is necessary.
data.author: Michele Visser-Fitton

data.text: I do too, but I find it too warm to cycle in. I use it for sleeping and rest days.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: we wear ours all the time except in the tropics, then it is too warm.
data.author: Michele Visser-Fitton

data.text: I get by not cleaning my clothes for some days easily. When it's hot and I pass a river or lake, I just wash my shirt and socks there. Otherwise I make a big wash at washing centres when I'm in a city
data.author: Hauke Kottek

data.text: We wash when we find a tap...any kind of tap. Easy in Muslim countries because there is mosques everywhere but in France there should be churches with toilets. Also we wash in coffee shops (where you can also charge) and really basically whenever we find a tap. We wash every day so we only have little laundry to wash so it's fast and not offensive. We charge with a solar panel most of the time and it works great.
data.author: Iris Mueller

data.text: yeah when I think about it this is so obvious. What do you do about showering though?
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: that's the easy part. We fill out water bladder and shower in the evening when we arrived at the wild camp spot or just go in the river/ pond/ stream whatever. As we don't use chemical washing gel it's possible whenever there is no audience :)
data.author: Iris Mueller

data.text: Use a wash cloth and a small amount of water from your bottles :-) filter the water if necessary? And maybe just embrace that being remote involves a bit of dirt and that's all part of the adventure :-)
data.author: Lizz White

data.text: If you're off-road and away from society, the definition of 'clean' can be whatever you want. :)
data.author: Tom Platts-Mills

data.text: Quick dry and a separate set of “town” clothes which I only use for going out
data.author: Gabe Gabe
